page.title: 03WILDLIFE IN HARVEL
page.content: Grade One SSSI's cover the Holly Hill and Crookhorn Valley areas. Scarp and valleys are rich in chalk flowers, including cowslips and stinking helle- bore, woodland bluebells, primroses, l7 orchid species in summer and Adders tongue fern. Clay-with-flints soils have common hedgerow and woodland flowers, ferns and fungi, and the pebbly capping on Holly Hill supports a large colony of lily-of-the-valley. The scarps are noted for butterflies, moths and grasshoppers. Migrant birds include grasshopper warblers. Tree pipits and nightjars nest in coppiced chestnut and nightingales sing in the valleys. Rabbits help control scrub on ungrazed scarp and valley slopes, where adders, slow worms and lizards are frequent. Badgers and foxes are common but deer are rare.
